headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, my name is Philip and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA's Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Hara, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good afternoon, my name is Philip and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA's Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Hara, you may begin your conference.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Philip. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011. With me on the call today are from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and David White, Chief Financial Officer
componenttext:
Thank you, Philip. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011. With me on the call today are from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and David White, Chief Financial Officer. 
After our prepared remarks, we will open up the call to question-and-answer session. Please limit yourself to one initial question with one follow-up question.
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that today's call is being webcast live on NVIDIA's Investor Relations website and is also being recorded. A replay of the conference call will be available via telephone until February 23, 2011. And the webcast will be available for replay until our conference call to discuss our financial results for our first quarter of fiscal 2012. 
The content of today's conference call is NVIDIA's property and cannot be reproduced or transcribed without our prior written consent.
During the course of this call, we may make forward-looking statements based on current expectations. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, and our actual results may differ materially. 
For a discussion of factors that could affect our future financial results and business, please refer to the disclosure in today's earnings release, our Form 10-Q for the fiscal period ended October 31, 2010 and the reports we may file from time to time on Form 8-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Our statements are made as of today, February 16, 2011 based on information available to us as of today and as except as required by law, we assume no obligation to update any such statements. Unless otherwise noted, all references the market research and market share numbers throughout the call come from Mercury Research or Jon Peddie Research. 
I would also like to remind everyone about our upcoming financial analyst day on March 8 taking place at our headquarters in Santa Clara. If you are interested in attending, you can register on our investor website.
With that, let's begin.
Last month, NVIDIA and shipped over 1 billionth GeForce GPU. This milestone is less than 12 years in the making and over that period of time, complexity of the GPU has increased more than 1000x. 
Having advanced from being the sixth function graphics accelerator to one of the most powerful programmable computing devices in the world, the GPU is enabling enormous progress in computers ranging from smartphones and tablets to PCs to game and game consoles to work stations of supercomputers. And in that time, the GPU has become the defining technology for every platform that uses it.
Our new $1.5 billion cross-licensing agreement with Intel underscores the growing importance of the GPU to the future of personal computing, as well as the expanding markets for mobile and cloud computing.
Heading into the year, we have one of the best lines of GPUs and the company's history. The GTX 580 remains at a top spot as the fastest DX11 GPU enthusiast gamers. We extended our DX11 technology leadership with the launch of the GTX 570 and the GTX 560 Ti helded by the reviewers and category leaders of $349 and $249 core gamer price segments. 
Our GTX products stack is the gamers choice and the results show. For the second consecutive quarter, our desktop standalone GPU share grew increasing from 59% in Q3 to 61% in Q4, with higher share gains in the performance and enthusiast segments.
And aside from our expectation to continue to gain share, there is several big events this year that can be a catalyst for growth. First, Intel Sandy Bridge is the best gamer CPU in the longtime. And with the SLI motherboards from Intel, Asus, Gigabyte and others, along with a new GTX 560 Ti, that offers gamers a perfect opportunity to upgrade their PC.
Second, great games drive GeForce GTX sales. And this year, we expect to see a number highly anticipated games such as Crisis 2, Battlefield 3, Forever, Portal 2 and The Outlaw 3. 
And third, 3D Vision is all about enjoying games at a whole new level. Driven by great new 3D Vision licensed products such as Acer's new 27-inch 3D Vision palm and Dell's SPX 17-inch 3D Vision notebook, we expect the 3D Vision to grow 200% this year. NVIDIA's 3D Vision content ecosystem is largest in the industry, the support for over 500 videogames, Blu-ray movies, and our new 3D Web portal, 3DVisionLive.com, which offers a wealth of streaming video and photographs.
In notebooks, we announced the number of record number of divine wins for the Intel Sandy Bridge platform. More than 200 new notebook models will feature our new GeForce 500M Series GPUs. Adding GeForce is one of the best ways for OEMs to differentiate PCs with premium capabilities versus the basic platforms based on Intel's graphics.
Unlike basic graphics integrated into Sandy Bridge CPUs,  GeForce GPUs provide advanced features and increased compatibility for latest PC games including those based on DX11. 
Tesla achieved over $100 million in revenue in fiscal 2011. Its becoming conventional with them in technical computing. Parallel processing delivers the highest performance, as well as being the most energy efficient and cost-effective.
The world's greatest pedal flops supercomputers are built with Tesla GPUs. The Green 500 lives for the world's most energy-efficient supercomputers revealed at Subami 2.0 from the Tokyo and soon technology ranked number two and was the only petaflop technology in the top 10. Three other Tesla-based systems made the top 10 along with persistent 11th, 12th and 13th spots. During the quarter, HP, Dell and IBM all entered into production with our Tesla-powered servers.
With the sales and market of the world's largest enterprise sales force engaged, we look forward to exhilarating the adoption of Tesla.
Technical computing servers enterprise them in the cloud represent the multibillion dollar growth opportunity for Tesla.
CES was the a coming-out for our Tegra 2 customers. Motorola, LG, Acer, Asus, and Toshiba all announced their flagships, smartphones and tablets tremendous industry claim at CES. The Motorola Xoom was Android 3.0, won overall best of show. And the Atrix won best of show in the smartphone category. And LG begin shipments for the Optimus 2X in Korea in January.
At CES, we also unveiled our long-term processor initiative code named Project Denver, to develop custom CPU cores based on the arm architecture. This initiative is focused on NVIDIA's CPU running the arm instruction set, which will be fully integrated as the same chip as the NVIDIA GPU. It will target personal computer, servers and supercomputers.
In addition to Audi, which we have enjoyed a deep partnership since 2004, we announced two new partnerships at CES with BMW North America and Tesla Motors. That will put NVIDIA processes in navigation vehicle information systems across all next generation BMW cars worldwide. And its tough to model us, respectively.
And this week at the Mobile World Congress, Samsung joined our marquee list of customers announcing their Galaxy Tab 10.1. And their plans for a next generation Tegra 2 superphone. LG also officially announced new Optimus pad, which will be the g-slate for T-Mobile.
Our highlighted MWC, with the demonstration of CALEL, the world's first mobile quad core processor, CALEL, our next generation Tegra SOC, which features a new 12-core GPU, provides 5x the performance of Tegra 2.
We're being at the example CAL to our strategic partners. And based on our competition announcements, we believe we are at least a year ahead of them. We are targeting to deliver CAL and tablets and smartphones later this year.
Our strategy with Tegra is to utilize our deep expertise in IP in computing to create processes for the mobile computing revolution. We designed Tegra to be the most advanced processor for mobile applications and to target the tablet segment, which is expected to be approximately 208 million units by 2014. 
In the smartphone segment, which is growing at a compounded 19% annual growth rate to approximately 600 million units in five years, as is submitted by the Gartner Group. And now, with Microsoft's announcements, Tegra can directly access the Windows PC market. 
Heading into Q1, our primary focus is to continue to ramp both our GeForce in Sandy Bridge and Tegra 2 customers into production.
More importantly, our results are beginning to tell the bigger story about NVIDIA's transformation. Even as we are expanding our leadership in digital computing, our investments in Tegra, Tesla, Project Denver, clears out of the two most disruptive revolution tapping with mobile and Cloud Computing. We're never been more optimistic about our growth opportunities.
With that, let me turn over the call over to David.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Revenue for the fourth quarter was $886.4 million, up 5% sequentially. Gross margin of 48.1% was a record for the second consecutive quarter. It was at the high-end of our range, primarily as a result of Richard's GPU product mix that we had
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Revenue for the fourth quarter was $886.4 million, up 5% sequentially. Gross margin of 48.1% was a record for the second consecutive quarter. It was at the high-end of our range, primarily as a result of Richard's GPU product mix that we had expected at the beginning of the quarter.
GAAP OpEx was $247 million. This includes the Intel settlement of $57 million. Without it, our R&D and SG&A costs would've been a combined $304 million in line with our estimates.
Combining these results generated a GAAP net income of $171.4 million or $0.29 per diluted share. Revenue by business segment was as follows: Our GPU business was up 5.5%; our MCP revenue was down significantly as we enter the final phase of that business, but this was more than offset by strong growth in desktop and notebook discretely.
Our professional business was down slightly. Quadro was down but this was some completely offset by strong growth in Tesla. Our Consumer business was up despite a seasonally down counsel business thanks to a strong Tegra of customer ramps.
Turning to the balance sheet. Our focus on inventory reduction continue to make progress as we were able to reduce it by another 8.5% to $345.5 million. Channel inventory was at or below expectations.
These results together with receipt of our first payment from Intel, allowed us to report cash balances of approximately $2.5 billion. Our outlook for the first quarter of fiscal 2012 is as follows:  Revenues expected to be up 6% to 8% from the fourth quarter; GAAP gross margin is expected to be 48.5% to 49.5%; GAAP operating expenses are expected to be approximately $327 million; GAAP tax rate is expected to be between 16% and 18%.
That concludes our prepared remarks. And with that, we'll now take questions.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: Well, it's probably mixed. We launched three new products at the top of our product lineup, as Mike talked about in his comments. And those are all higher ASPs for the company. So they drove not only ASPs for a us but they also drove margin for us.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: At Mobile World Congress, it seems like everyone is raising, and this is for Mike, you launched quad core. But the question I have on quad core is, is there enough application now to take advantage of this level of power you're bringing at the end of this
componenttext: At Mobile World Congress, it seems like everyone is raising, and this is for Mike, you launched quad core. But the question I have on quad core is, is there enough application now to take advantage of this level of power you're bringing at the end of this year? And then secondly, do you need 28 nanometers to make this profitably, by the economics of that efficiency?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Quad core, it is the case that several of our competitors announced quad core products that will be sampled next year and potentially go into production the year after. At Mobile World Congress, we demonstrated CALEL and there were quite a few systems on-
componenttext: Quad core, it is the case that several of our competitors announced quad core products that will be sampled next year and potentially go into production the year after. At Mobile World Congress, we demonstrated CALEL and there were quite a few systems on-hand for demonstrating all aspects of CALEL whether it was extreme high-definition video, has the ability to support very high definition displays, the overall horsepower and computational capability of about CALEL is about 5x the performance of Tegra 2. And has some really exciting new technologies for extremely low power operations, even though we have four CPUs inside our CALEL processor. These are all the breakthroughs that we have demonstrated at Mobile World Congress. Whereas some of the competitors seemed panicked to announce something on their powerpoint slides. We tend to announce the product when we're actually sampling to customers. And in the case of CALEL, we're now sampling to our strategic partners. And our intention is to go to production this year. With respect to the importance of quad core, obviously, quad core is incredibly important. Otherwise, it would not be on all over the suppliers roadmaps. We were the first in the world to announce and ship dual core. During that time, a lot of people asked us about that. And now, its quad core. If you think about the tablet or mobile device applications, you'll realize that very quickly you're multitasking. you're multitasking whether you're streaming music, while you're reading a book or you're playing game and you're being connected to other players in a multiplayer environment. For do physics processing while you're playing the game. One of the most delightful parts of the games that people like these days whether it's Angry Bird or others, is just a realistic physics that it does. And the way that the brakes and the buildings fall apart our physically real. And you'll see more and more of that type of capability over time. And so whether it's the multitasking, whether it's image processing for a very high-quality camera effects, browsing, multitasking, those type of applications are all very buried in terms of users of multi course. And the last thing is it's actually logical and completely intuitive if you think about it. But four CPU cores working less hard consumes less energy than one CPU core or two CPU cores working their butt off. That's the reason why if you look at the PC industry, what people have said about the PC heading to brick wall and hitting the power wall, remember when CPUs were cranking at extremely high frequencies, those are just bad ideas. Brute forcing CPU design and overclocking it and causing it to run extremely fast is just not a very good idea. It makes a lot more sense to run it at the natural frequency of the semiconductor process and utilize all kinds of parallels and ideas. In the case of CPUs, we have four cores. In the case of GPU, we have 12 cores. Using parallelism is the most efficient and also the highest performance approach to computing that we know.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Economic would be 28 nanometers?
componenttext: Economic would be 28 nanometers?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, 28 nanometers is not available yet. So that's not an option this year. And the other hand, 40-nanometer is actually more economical than 28 nanometers this year and will likely expect to be so until about first half, maybe even the midpoint of next
componenttext: Well, 28 nanometers is not available yet. So that's not an option this year. And the other hand, 40-nanometer is actually more economical than 28 nanometers this year and will likely expect to be so until about first half, maybe even the midpoint of next year. So 40 nanometer is absolutely the right approach. It is the most mature and we can go into a very, very high production, very, very quickly because the yields are so great.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Amrish Srivastava.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Amrish Srivastava.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: For the Tegra business, can you comment on the mix of that between smartphones and tablets today? And where you see that as you exit the year?
componenttext: For the Tegra business, can you comment on the mix of that between smartphones and tablets today? And where you see that as you exit the year?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard to tell because it depends on how many smartphones and tablets are partners itself. And so it's really, really hard to tell. One of the things that we all have to recognize is the market for tablets is much, much larger than we've all expe
componenttext: Well, it's hard to tell because it depends on how many smartphones and tablets are partners itself. And so it's really, really hard to tell. One of the things that we all have to recognize is the market for tablets is much, much larger than we've all expected. And every single time an analyst comes up with another protection for the size of tablet market, it gets bigger. And I think there's a couple of reasons for that. This is wonderfully delightful to use, they're easy to carry around and you see more and more people now carrying around tablets instead of, surely instead of -- I've never seen anybody carry a netbook around, but you see more and more people carry tablets around than notebooks. And also, even if you have a PC, you don't mind buying a tablet to supplement it. You always have a PC its not likely you buy another PC but you surely would buy a tablet to supplement it. So I think it's an easy purchase, it's easy to use and delightful to use. And so I think people are surprised by the size of the tablet market. My sense that we continue to be surprised by the size of the tablet market, certainly as more and more capabilities come out. One of the things that we're really excited about is that these tablets are now completely flash accelerated and so you can go to any website, you could rent any application off the web that you in respect to. So those kinds of new usage capabilities and this freedom to explore capability is something that we're quite excited about. So it's hard for us to tell right now. The thing that I can tell you is that our design wins are all Tier ones. These are the marquee names of the mobile industry and the computing industry and have a great deal of faith in their ability to create exciting products and taking them to market. So we'll just have to wait and see, see how it turns out.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Within the GPU segment, can you comment on your expectation for ASPs on desktops and notebooks as the Sandy Bridge systems are rolled out?
componenttext: Within the GPU segment, can you comment on your expectation for ASPs on desktops and notebooks as the Sandy Bridge systems are rolled out?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our ASPs, it depends on two factors. On the one hand, most of the notebook ASPs are going to be lower than the GTX 580 and 570 to 560 we just recently rolled out. On the other hand, the GTX 570 and 560 are still ramping. And so it's hard to say exactly ho
componenttext: Our ASPs, it depends on two factors. On the one hand, most of the notebook ASPs are going to be lower than the GTX 580 and 570 to 560 we just recently rolled out. On the other hand, the GTX 570 and 560 are still ramping. And so it's hard to say exactly how it's going to play out. We're just going to have to report on the progress as we go. We're excited about the gamers market. The gamers market has three catalysts this year. One, there's some really, really big titles of PC games coming out. Crisis 2 is just really is exciting and so I think the enthusiasts come out when there is a great new breakthrough games like Crisis. The second thing is, its been a long time since the PC gamers had a basic platform of great opportunity. Sandy Bridge is the best CPU that's been built on for PC gamers in a long, long time. And so we have is a SLI motherboards with Intel, we have SLI motherboards with Asus Tech, with Gigabyte, with many others so that gamers can upgrade their PCs with affordable, very low-powered and very high-performance systems. And so when Sandy Bridge starts to ramp and the SLI motherboards start the ship in the near future, We going to have to see how many people come up for the upgrade. And lastly, there's a 3D Vision when you can enjoy looking into 3D, its much more exciting. And 3D Vision basically doubles the resolution. One for each eye, doubles the resolution that is needed to enjoy the game. So that tends to drive higher end ASPs. So we just going to have to wait and see what we can tell for sure.

Our notebook business is going to go very nicely in Q1, primarily as a result of the Sandy Bridge platforms that will be shipping in the quarter. And we expect obviously Tesla and Tegra to continue growing and helping drive our revenue growth going into the new fiscal year.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: On Tegra, obviously, the team has a rapid ramp ahead of them and I think the concern with anything associated with the mobile and retail space is how do you monitor sell-through to the end markets and to consumers. And then to kind of triangulate that wit
componenttext: On Tegra, obviously, the team has a rapid ramp ahead of them and I think the concern with anything associated with the mobile and retail space is how do you monitor sell-through to the end markets and to consumers. And then to kind of triangulate that with the orders that you're getting from your handset and your tablet customers? So maybe you can take us through how the team plans to keep a close eye on sell-through to your customers versus sell-through to the end markets?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the way we look at that is -- in our larger businesses like Quadro, and GeForce, we put a lot of energy into monitoring sellouts and sell-throughs. The reason for that is we're in such a large position in the marketplace. Tegra is a brand new produc
componenttext: Well, the way we look at that is -- in our larger businesses like Quadro, and GeForce, we put a lot of energy into monitoring sellouts and sell-throughs. The reason for that is we're in such a large position in the marketplace. Tegra is a brand new product for us and we have almost zero exposure in the mobile industry and this is really our first major push into it. And the devices that we're in are not fringe or exotic devices. They're not transformer-type devices or new 3D displays where people aren't sure yet whether those adoptions are quite higher or not. These are straight down the middle, high-end and where the demand is the greatest superphone devices right now. And as you see from the device, they're beautiful and they're the primary platforms for the marquee customers that we're working with. It is core to their business, these aren't fringe products. And so I think that from that perspective, I have relative amount of confidence that our partners will do a great job in marketing them. And the enthusiasm in the marketplace is already really, really high. Had to read sources that we will do quite well as we get to the be a much larger player in the mobile space, we're going to have to develop those kind of systems that we use for the PC industry where we monitor sellthroughs and sellouts. So better job with that. But at the moment I think that we're going into I guess what people what consider.

componenttext: And then when we look at some of the OpEx number, it looks like this quarter, you're planning on OpEx growth, looks a little bit above the revenue guided especially if we were to strip out the $20 million royalty payment. Can you comment on what we should think about OpEx both in Q1 and throughout the balance of the year given the need to support all the Tegra programs?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we included in the CFO commentary, a lot of what's driving -- the really two largest components that are driving operating expense really are the fact our stock price has gone up and that's driving stock-based compensation. Another piece is hirin
componenttext: Well, as we included in the CFO commentary, a lot of what's driving -- the really two largest components that are driving operating expense really are the fact our stock price has gone up and that's driving stock-based compensation. Another piece is hiring and engineering support materials and so forth for all the products of our launching. In some of those investments we're making that are coming in Q1, perceived revenue that we hope to realize later on in the year as we see Tesla and Tegra and other pieces of our business ramping. As it relates to 327 that we guided for Q1 and how that's going to behave going forward, we won't have for example, payroll tax for the full year so forth. And that will naturally go down and some other expenses will offset that. But I wouldn't expect that to be appreciably higher going to the year when you net all those things out.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's inappropriate to not include royalties as part of our ongoing business. There's several businesses in our company where royalties is the natural way for us to engage our customers. And it does require innovation and engineering invention for
componenttext: I think it's inappropriate to not include royalties as part of our ongoing business. There's several businesses in our company where royalties is the natural way for us to engage our customers. And it does require innovation and engineering invention for us to benefit from those royalties. So I think the two go hand-in-hand, I wouldn't expect it to be in so for us, going forward.

componenttext: The answer is in the mobile space, there's just a lot of system software. And it is developing multimedia and systems offer technology is one of the areas where we just have an enormous amount of expertise because of building sophisticated over the years. If you look at the PC, the amount of system software we have to do for that is every bit now the same in the mobile industry, if not more. And that's one of the reasons why we believe that the mobile computing world is going to be such a great opportunity for us. That on one hand, the model will continue to be important. On the other hand, for certain classes or devices, whether its the superphones or tablets, it's computing capability is one of the most important things. And in order to deliver on a great computing experience, the ability to great of the systems software from video to graphic to multitasking to all of the flash accelerations and just the enormous amount of OpenGL and computer vision and imaging software, all of that kind of software working together in a really wonderful experience is hard to pull together and this is something that we believe we have a great deal of expertise and a great deal of capacity to do. So we do quite a large amount of it. We know our architecture best, this is an area that in terms of system software, a few companies in the world has a very large capacity to do. The three companies that probably have the largest capacity in the world of system software is probably us, Intel and AMD because of all the computers that have been built over the years. We just have more people in systems software with this expertise in just anywhere else in the world. I think this is something that is of great importance and is becoming more and more important and greater and greater. And early reviews of Tegra 2 phones. Some of the comments that people are making are its stability and the performance of these phones right off the chute. Most of the smartphones that you may have bought with the exception of Apple's products frankly, you had to debug into existence. And you know, we think that's not inherent to a phone because its inheritability to great computers. So I think this is an quick differentiation for us.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: So this is one of the differentiators. You've got a very aggressive roadmap that you showed on Tegra. As we move forward, what are the key differentiators other than what you just talked about in the tablet market and the handset market from your perspect
componenttext: So this is one of the differentiators. You've got a very aggressive roadmap that you showed on Tegra. As we move forward, what are the key differentiators other than what you just talked about in the tablet market and the handset market from your perspective? And overtime, given the integration trends, at least in the handset market, if the lack of baseband and connectivity are material constraint or not for you in your view?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Computing is a very large space. And although these mobile devices are starting to do more and more computing, the computing capability that we're looking at is still rather nascent. The benefit that we have is, and we described it at the Mobile World Con
componenttext: Computing is a very large space. And although these mobile devices are starting to do more and more computing, the computing capability that we're looking at is still rather nascent. The benefit that we have is, and we described it at the Mobile World Congress, the benefit that we have is that the rich and deep pipeline of intellectual property that we can bring to bare as mobile devices become more and more computing capable. We went from a company that was working on basically one and a half to two mobile chips to a company that now has five chips on the roadmap. And we're concurrently working on projects that go all the way up to 20 nanometers and beyond. We don't have to wait for anyone to create the computing technology for us to license. We have all the technology here for us to bring the bear and execute a really aggressive roadmap. And that's how we're able to year-end year out, crank out products that industry is just putting it on paper. With respect to motives, they're quite a few in the model players in the world. road how many of there are obviously, supplier ST, Ericsson, there are many others. And our focus is on the segments of the marketplace where computing is really important. And we believe that there's a great deal of work that we do here before we need to consider increasing levels of integration. And then lastly, both the computing side and the motives side are going through very rapid innovation at the moment. On the one hand, computing is going from dual core to quad core and more and more our GPU performance, better, and better video capabilities in such. And on the other hand, modems are going from 2.5G to 3G to 4G. All of these are moving parts. Integration is the enemy of innovation. And so it's hard to move as fast when you have to integrate everything to one show.

componenttext: And then just to take a step back, you have guided Tegra. What are your guidance for Tegra for the year? And how have you seen a change on the downside as you gone to the last couple of quarters through the year?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have not guided Tegra for the year. Probably, the new piece of information about Tegra that is CALEL going to position this year. I don't think anybody expected us to announce that. I don't think anybody expect us to have a roadmap that was this aggres
componenttext: We have not guided Tegra for the year. Probably, the new piece of information about Tegra that is CALEL going to position this year. I don't think anybody expected us to announce that. I don't think anybody expect us to have a roadmap that was this aggressive and was a surprise to all of our competitors and a surprise to many of our customers. And so all of our partners are in retooling mode right now in roadmap so that they can catch up to us on CALEL. I'm excited about the second half of the year as the tablet market continues to develop and as we go into CALEL. So that's the new piece of information that I think people realize and consider.

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Tim Luke.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, as you look at the revenue momentum, having had a strong uptick into April as you start the Tegra ramp, do you feel that, that's sort of rate of growth may be sustainable through into the July period or is it to some extent that you had a
componenttext: I was wondering, as you look at the revenue momentum, having had a strong uptick into April as you start the Tegra ramp, do you feel that, that's sort of rate of growth may be sustainable through into the July period or is it to some extent that you had a big midterm that initial supply into the channel? And I was wondering, Jen-Hsun if you could have in the framework with this expectation of the timeline that you talked about Tegra 3?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, we barely shipped anything. So Tegra 2 has just barely gone into production. In terms of thinking about these things, the growth and the growth opportunities, really, the only thing you can keep in mind this is the size of the opportunity at
componenttext: First of all, we barely shipped anything. So Tegra 2 has just barely gone into production. In terms of thinking about these things, the growth and the growth opportunities, really, the only thing you can keep in mind this is the size of the opportunity at our partners that you have to address those opportunities. The size of the tablet opportunities, obviously, is larger than anybody expected. And I think people are getting a firmer grip on why the tablet is such a wonderful computing device. Secondly, I think the partners that we are going to market are undoubtedly the best in the world. We have to choose the best Android partners in the world. I think we've captured is the better. And so I think we're going to be able to address a very large market and address it with partners who could give us a global reach. With respect to the future Tegras, I'm not sure if there was any exact question. But I haven't used the word Tegra 3 yet, but we've demonstrated recently a processor called CALEL, it's an internal code name for a next generation processor. We haven't figured out -- we haven't decided yet what the market that is going to be. It is intended to be in production in Q3.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: And just to David, on OpEx if I may, have you seen the guidance move of around the $25 million, in the April quarter. Do you think the rates of growth in OpEx through the next several quarters to support the customers is likely to be in a similar range? or do think the magnitude of the sequential increases could be somewhat lower?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, I think the magnitude of quarter-over-quarter after Q1 should be much lower. And you've got two step functions that kind of an impact in Q1. One was the restart of payroll taxes, which is pretty binary. And then the second one is just the recent run-
componenttext: Tim, I think the magnitude of quarter-over-quarter after Q1 should be much lower. And you've got two step functions that kind of an impact in Q1. One was the restart of payroll taxes, which is pretty binary. And then the second one is just the recent run-up in our stock, as caused our stock-based compensation to go up quite handedly as while. So we'll have to wait and see what happens with stock price, but certainly the FICA will be going and going to reset again. I think in terms of our controllable total expenses in terms of engineering, materials and grants and all those things able causes so forth, I would expect it to be rising as much of it did from Q4 to Q1.

componenttext: Well, the royalty or license fee from Intel will contribute $2.5 million to $3 million of gross margin starting in the second quarter. If you hold that out and just look at our core business, gross margins there should also be increasing through the year as well, particularly as Tesla and Tegra products ramp and I think even as our desktop business in our high-end GTX 560, 570 and 580 products continue to gain momentum out in the marketplace. So certainly, we see a path for our margins being well into the low 50s sometime during the year.

componenttext: If I just do a little bit of math there, it should almost be conceivable that you can exit the year at somewhere in mid-50s. Is that unrealistic?

componenttext: We'll just have to wait and see. We've got a lot of second half of the year as a got a lot of unknowns. At this point particularly some of the new businesses. So we certainly like to think that we will have a very nice back end into the year and though contribute to margin up will just have to wait.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Kevin Cassidy.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Kevin Cassidy.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jen, you had mentioned 40-nanometer. I wonder if you tell me more about the time-to-market or is it even your customers requests? I just want to understand that a little more.
componenttext: Jen, you had mentioned 40-nanometer. I wonder if you tell me more about the time-to-market or is it even your customers requests? I just want to understand that a little more.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, 28 nanometers is not available this year, not until the very end of the year. And I think for us to ship production out in Q3, we have to start wafers in early Q2. And so 28 nanometers is not an option. And secondarily, 40 nanometers i
componenttext: Well, first of all, 28 nanometers is not available this year, not until the very end of the year. And I think for us to ship production out in Q3, we have to start wafers in early Q2. And so 28 nanometers is not an option. And secondarily, 40 nanometers is now in the third year of its production. And the yields are fabulous. And so that's a wonderful reason to do it. So I think in the one hand, 28 nanometers is available on the other hand, 28 nanometers. I think it's just a natural right answer. But going forward, the way I think about it is the general rhythm that you'll see in the industry for a company that come up with new processes every year, you should expect to see two processors in the same node or so. You notice other companies have used different ways of explaining the rhythm and some use one process note change one is an architecture change, the next one is a process change. Basically, its every other year for a new process note. And I think that rhythm is not a. That's basically how quickly the industry is this process. Tegra 2 or Tegra Next will CALEL will use the same process and the following ones 20-nanometer deal.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Shawn Webster.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Shawn Webster.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. On Tegra, is there a break even run rate that you guys need for you to be breaking even on operating margin basis now?
componenttext: A couple of questions. On Tegra, is there a break even run rate that you guys need for you to be breaking even on operating margin basis now?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: The answer is it's hard to predict and the reason for that is this. More and more of our company is evolved in the Tegra roadmap. So quickly as Tegra is growing, more of our companies overall R&D is driving into the Tegra roadmap. It is because it's great
componenttext: The answer is it's hard to predict and the reason for that is this. More and more of our company is evolved in the Tegra roadmap. So quickly as Tegra is growing, more of our companies overall R&D is driving into the Tegra roadmap. It is because it's great from mobile devices, smartphones, tablets and because of Microsoft's announcement with Windows Next, running on ARM, all of a sudden Tegra has the ability to address front and center dead-on the core notebook PC market. And I think the opportunity to take a future generation processors indirectly into the number of markets is really excited to me and it's also a way for the PC industry to really be revolutionized, if you will, with industrial designs that are exquisite and better. Usage models are very, very different than today's notebook. I think it's pretty clear at this point that in the future, Windows notebooks will make today's notebooks look a little bit like refrigerators. I think that we have the ability to revolutionize how people see notebook computers again and I'm excited about that. And so how much of our engineering should really go into Tegra? And related Denver plus Tesla, the answer is a lot. And so the break even point is eventually come.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And switching gears, but on your core GPU and chipset business, what is the size of the chipset business for you to today just in the sense of the trajectory where we're sitting now in the next couple of quarters? And also, can you share us what GPU units
componenttext: And switching gears, but on your core GPU and chipset business, what is the size of the chipset business for you to today just in the sense of the trajectory where we're sitting now in the next couple of quarters? And also, can you share us what GPU units did sequentially for Q4?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the MCB business, Shawn, I think we've talked previously about that business roughly running its course for the most part for the first half this fiscal '12. And then the second half of the year, it should be pretty minor piece of our business. We have
componenttext: On the MCB business, Shawn, I think we've talked previously about that business roughly running its course for the most part for the first half this fiscal '12. And then the second half of the year, it should be pretty minor piece of our business. We have not broken out beyond that other than to say at least at this point, we know that Tegra will exceed it in Q1. And as far as units are concerned, our units were up in the fourth quarter, primarily on the strength of our mainstream business. But more importantly, the revenue per unit on the ASPs driven primarily by our mix changes. And we're happy to see that, it drives a lot of earnings potential for the company and opportunities for the company. And we don't right now see that changing materially, going forward.

componenttextpreview: Let me just give you some directional input. Our ASPs is for tablets, because the package is larger and the bin intends to be a little higher. Our tablet margins, our ASPs are higher than the smartphones. Smartphones are also designed into depending on wh
componenttext: Let me just give you some directional input. Our ASPs is for tablets, because the package is larger and the bin intends to be a little higher. Our tablet margins, our ASPs are higher than the smartphones. Smartphones are also designed into depending on which tier of the customers we engage with, extremely high-volume engagements or moderate volume engagements that goes ASPs tends to go lower than tablets. And CALEL, as the world's first quad core, we commend a premium when the product come out. So those are the directional, we haven't broken up much.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you just address your notebook GPU share as we head through this year? Clearly, you're getting share obviously in several platforms. Do you think that's up in Q1 and Q2 and they kind of those as we add to that the backup of the year? Or do think it'
componenttext: Could you just address your notebook GPU share as we head through this year? Clearly, you're getting share obviously in several platforms. Do you think that's up in Q1 and Q2 and they kind of those as we add to that the backup of the year? Or do think it's more of a gradual continuing throughout the year?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Most of that depends on how quickly Intel is going to transition Sandy Bridge relative to Huang river, I think with the last platform. If Intel gets aggressive with Sandy River, our share of Sandy River is much, much higher than that of Huang River. As yo
componenttext: Most of that depends on how quickly Intel is going to transition Sandy Bridge relative to Huang river, I think with the last platform. If Intel gets aggressive with Sandy River, our share of Sandy River is much, much higher than that of Huang River. As you recall, we lost market share on Huang River and we're the first firming generation. But the GTX, or the five family, the second-generation for me, has been a huge success for us. From desktop to notebook, we have the best pack of GPU today. And so more aggressively Intel transitions from Sandy revert to the more quickly we will gain share. So partly depends on that.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Glenn Young.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Glenn Young.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think somebody quoted a Gartner number for tablets in 2014. When you think about a number that big, what do you think is a realistic for it in NVIDIA's market share in that business?
componenttext: I think somebody quoted a Gartner number for tablets in 2014. When you think about a number that big, what do you think is a realistic for it in NVIDIA's market share in that business?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, who knows? 2014 is a long time from now. I think there's a couple of things that we believe in. We believe that computers are going to become thinner and thinner and easier and easier to use. And touch is going to become an increasing important part
componenttext: Well, who knows? 2014 is a long time from now. I think there's a couple of things that we believe in. We believe that computers are going to become thinner and thinner and easier and easier to use. And touch is going to become an increasing important part of computer. It stands to reason that tablets or notebooks that can become tablets or tablets that can become notebooks, that these are going to become, if you will, kind of part of computing. It will become the PC. And we consider it a tablet today but if you look at some of the way people are thinking about it, I think about it as personal computers. This is the new personal computer. And they're just different form factors. There are smaller versions of tablets, we call them smartphones or superphones. There are larger versions of tablets, we call them notebooks. There are even super large versions of tablets, if you will, all-in-one PC. And so I think that you're going to find an investor design of personal computers has become disruptive, if you will, as a result of mobile computing components being used and mobile computing processors being used. So I think that the space of personal computers, tablets, smartphones are going to become a little bit fuzzy over time. Even the OEMs that provide them will become fuzzy overtime. And it stands to reason that at this point I think we all believe its a very large market. Now to be successful within our large market, it's important that you have very low-power design. Its important you have the arm processor. The ARM ISA has now become the de facto standard of this segment as a market and it's become very disruptive. It is the only ISA now that can support major operating systems necessary for the mobile computing space. From IOS the QNX to Android to now Next-generation Windows. So it's clear that we need that arm. And then after that, you need to have expertise in building computers. Whether in SOC, its basically a computer on a chip and when you are provider of computer on a chip, and there are this many operating systems to support, you better have the deep, deep expertise and not to mention capacity of system software's expertise in building sophisticated computers like this. And so I think at the very high level, it's really exactly how we think about our strategy. That this is a very large market, it is disruptive, it is disrupting the computer industry as we see it and we note it right now. And this is an area where we believe we can play at a great deal of making a great contribution and drive our growth. And aside from that, it's kind of hard to predict exactly Gartner whether it's going to be right or not. My guess is based on where the analysts' prediction are going lately, it seems like every month raising their estimates. And so we don't know where it stops.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your final question is from the line of Craig Berger.
componenttext: And your final question is from the line of Craig Berger.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the GPU business, a, is there an impact in April quarter from the Intel Sandy Bridge delayed? Is production being held up? And then, b, where is your notebook market share now and where do you expect it to go? And then as part of that, do you think San
componenttext: On the GPU business, a, is there an impact in April quarter from the Intel Sandy Bridge delayed? Is production being held up? And then, b, where is your notebook market share now and where do you expect it to go? And then as part of that, do you think Sandy Bridge is going to take any over all GPU share?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Number one, we have not experienced a disruption, so far, and people are still running as hard as they can. They pause but I think Intel is doing quite a good job of having everyone covered. With respect to share, I think our share is about 40% today, my
componenttext: Number one, we have not experienced a disruption, so far, and people are still running as hard as they can. They pause but I think Intel is doing quite a good job of having everyone covered. With respect to share, I think our share is about 40% today, my guess is that when it's all said and done, our share should be north of 60%. And then with respect to cash rate, the PC industry still has basically to two tiers: The basic PC and the premium PC. If every PC uses basic Intel integrated graphics, then everything would be the same and everything would become. But obviously, no consumer would like that. Because they still believe that there's an opportunity to buy a better PC and one that has higher performance or higher resolution or just more interactivity or the fact that our GPUs is far, far, far more compatible with games and all the multimedia applications. So it depends on how you want it, what you use it for. If you're a person looking for a basic PC then integrated graphics makes sense for you. And if you're looking for premium PC, and buy something a little bit better with the money you have. Adding the GPU is really a fabulous thing. And so that basic dynamic hasn't really change with the introduction of Sandy Bridge not expecting much GPU attached differences.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: You guys said you did about $100 million of Tesla this year. Do you care to throw out a number that we should dial into our models for 2011?
componenttext: You guys said you did about $100 million of Tesla this year. Do you care to throw out a number that we should dial into our models for 2011?

componenttext: It's hard to say, but we should grow very nicely this year. We will give you more guidance as we get closer to you.

componenttext: And no further questions at this time. Do you have any closing remarks?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, my name is Philip, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Hara, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good afternoon, my name is Philip, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Hara, you may begin your conference.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Philip. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011. With me on the call today are from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and David White, Chief Financial Officer
componenttext:
Thank you, Philip. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011. With me on the call today are from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and David White, Chief Financial Officer. After our prepared remarks, we will open up the call to question-and-answer session. Please limit yourself to one initial question with one follow-up question.
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that today's call is being webcast live on NVIDIA's Investor Relations website and is also being recorded. A replay of the conference call will be available via telephone until February 23, 2011, and the webcast will be available for replay until our conference call to discuss our financial results for our first quarter fiscal 2012. The content of today's conference call is NVIDIA's property and cannot be reproduced or transcribed without our prior written consent.
During the course of this call, we may make forward-looking statements based on current expectations. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, and our actual results may differ materially. For a discussion of factors that could affect our future financial results and business, please refer to the disclosure in today's earnings release, our Form 10-Q for the fiscal period ended October 31, 2010, and the reports we may file from time to time on Form 8-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
All our statements are made as of today, February 16, 2011, based on information available to us as of today and except as required by law, we assume no obligation to update any such statements. Unless otherwise noted, all references to market research and market share numbers throughout the call come from Mercury Research or Jon Peddie Research. 
I would also like to remind everyone about our upcoming financial analyst day on March 8, taking place at our headquarters in Santa Clara. If you are interested in attending, you can register on our investor website. With that, let's begin.
Last month, NVIDIA and TSMC shipped our 1 billionth GeForce GPU. This milestone is less than 12 years in the making, and over that period of time, the complexity of the GPU has increased more than 1,000x. Having advanced from being a fixed-function graphics accelerator to one of the most powerful programmable computing devices in the world, the GPU is enabling enormous progress in computers ranging from smartphones and tablets to PCs and game consoles to work stations and supercomputers. And in that time, the GPU has become the defining technology for every platform that uses it. Our new $1.5 billion cross-licensing agreement with Intel underscores the growing importance of the GPU to the future of personal computing as well as to the expanding markets for mobile and cloud computing.
Heading into the year, we have one of the best line ups of GPUs in the company's history. The GTX 580 remains in the top spot as the fastest DX11 GPU for enthusiast gamers. We extended our DX11 technology leadership with the launch of the GTX 570 and the GTX 560 Ti, heralded by reviewers as category leaders for the $349 and $249 core gamer price segments. 
Our GTX product stack is the gamers' choice and the results show. For the second consecutive quarter, our desktop standalone GPU share grew increasing from 59% in Q3 to 61% in Q4, with higher share gains in the performance and enthusiasts segments. And aside from our expectation to continue to gain share, there are several big events this year that can be catalysts for growth. First, Intel Sandy Bridge is the best gamer CPU in a long time. And with the SLI motherboards from Intel, ASUS, Gigabyte and others, along with the new GTX 560 Ti, it offers gamers a perfect opportunity to upgrade their PC.
Second, great games drive GeForce GTX sales. And this year, we expect to see a number highly anticipated games such as Crysis 2, Battlefield 3, Duke Nukem Forever, Portal 2 and Diablo III. And third, 3D Vision is all about enjoying games at a whole new level. Driven by great new 3D Vision licensed products such as Acer's new 27-inch 3D Vision panel and Dell's XPS 17-inch 3D Vision notebook, we expect the 3D Vision to grow 200% this year. NVIDIA's 3D Vision content ecosystem is the largest in the industry, the support for over 500 video games, Blu-ray movies, and our new 3D Web portal, 3dvisionlive.com, which offers a wealth of streaming video and photographs.
In notebooks, we announced a record number of design wins for the Intel Sandy Bridge platform. More than 200 new notebook models will feature our new GeForce 500M Series GPUs. Adding GeForce is one of the best ways for OEMs to differentiate PCs with premium capabilities versus the basic platforms based on Intel's graphics. Unlike basic graphics integrated in the Sandy Bridge CPUs,  GeForce GPUs provide advanced features and increased compatibility for latest PC games including those based on DX11. 
Tesla achieved over $100 million in revenue in fiscal 2011. Its becoming conventional with them in technical computing that parallel processing delivers the highest performance as well as being the most energy efficient and cost-effective. The world's greatest petaflops and supercomputers are built with Tesla GPUs. The Green500 list for the world's most energy-efficient supercomputers revealed that Tsubame 2.0 from the Tokyo Institute of Technology was ranked number two and was the only petaflop system in the top 10. Three other Tesla-based systems made the top 10 along with recipients in 11th, 12th and 13th spots. During the quarter, HP, Dell and IBM all entered into production with our Tesla-powered servers. With the sales and market of the world's largest enterprise sales force engaged, we look forward to exhilarating the adoption of Tesla. Technical computing servers enterprise in the cloud represents the multibillion dollar growth opportunity for Tesla.
CES was the coming-out party for our Tegra 2 customers. Motorola, LG, Acer, ASUS, and Toshiba all announced their flagship smartphones and tablets with tremendous industry claim at CES. The MOTOROLA XOOM with Android 3.0 won overall Best of Show. And the ATRIX won Best of Show in the smartphone category. And LG began shipment for the Optimus 2X in Korea in January.
At CES, we also unveiled our long-term processor initiative code named Project Denver, to develop custom CPU cores based on the ARM architecture. This initiative is focused on NVIDIA's CPU running the ARM instruction set, which will be fully integrated in the same chip as the NVIDIA GPU. It will target personal computers, servers and supercomputers.
In addition to Audi, which we have enjoyed a deep partnership since 2004, we announced two new partnerships at CES with BMW North America and Tesla Motors that will put NVIDIA processors and navigation and vehicle information systems across all next-generation BMW cars worldwide and the Tesla growth for Model S, respectively.
In this week at the Mobile World Congress, Samsung joined our marquee list of customers announcing their Galaxy Tab 10.1 and their plans for a next-generation Tegra 2 superphone. LG also officially announced the new Optimus pad, which will be the G-Slate for T-Mobile.
A highlight at MWC for the demonstration of Kal-El, the world's first mobile quad core processor. Kal-El, our next-generation Tegra SOC, which features a new 12-core NVIDIA GPU, provides 5x the performance of Tegra 2. We're beginning to sample Kal-El to strategic partners. And based on our competition announcements, we believe we're at least a year ahead of them. We are targeting to deliver Kal-El in tablets and smartphones later this year.
Our strategy with Tegra is to utilize our deep expertise in IP and computing to create processors for the mobile computing revolution. We designed Tegra to be the most advanced processor for mobile applications and to target the tablet segment, which is expected to be approximately 208 million units by 2014. 
In the smartphone segment, which is growing at a compounded 19% annual growth rate to approximately 600 million units in five years as estimated by the Gartner Group. And now with Microsoft's announcement, Tegra can directly access the Windows PC market. 
Heading into Q1, our primary focus is to continue to ramp both our GeForce on Sandy Bridge and Tegra 2 customers into production. More importantly, our results are beginning to tell the bigger story about NVIDIA's transformation. Even as we are expanding our leadership in digital computing, our investments in Tegra, Tesla and Project Denver put us at the center of the two most disruptive revolution tapping with mobile and cloud computing. We have never been more optimistic about our growth opportunities.
With that, let me turn the call over to David.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Revenue for the fourth quarter was $886.4 million, up 5% sequentially. Gross margin of 48.1% was a record for the second consecutive quarter. It was at the high end of our range, primarily as a result of richer GPU product mix than we had ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Revenue for the fourth quarter was $886.4 million, up 5% sequentially. Gross margin of 48.1% was a record for the second consecutive quarter. It was at the high end of our range, primarily as a result of richer GPU product mix than we had expected the beginning of the quarter. GAAP OpEx was $247 million. This includes the Intel settlement of $57 million. Without it, our R&D and SG&A costs would have been a combined $304 million in line with our estimates.
Combining these results generated a GAAP net income of $171.4 million (sic) [$171.7 million] or $0.29 per diluted share. Revenue by business segment was as follows: Our GPU business was up 5.5%; our MCP revenue was down significantly as we entered into the final phase of that business, but this was more than offset by strong growth in desktop and notebook discrete. Our Professional business was down slightly. Quadro was down, but this was almost completely offset by strong growth in Tesla. And our Consumer business was up despite a seasonally down console business thanks to a strong Tegra customer ramps.
Turning to the balance sheet. Our focus on inventory reduction continue to make progress as we were able to reduce it by another 8.5% to $345.5 million. Channel inventory was at or below expectations. These results, together with receipt of our first payment from Intel, allowed us to report cash balances of approximately $2.5 billion. Our outlook for the first quarter of fiscal 2012 is as follows:  Revenue is expected to be up 6% to 8% from the fourth quarter; GAAP gross margin is expected to be 48.5% to 49.5%; GAAP operating expenses are expected to be approximately $327 million; GAAP tax rate is expected to be between 16% and 18%.
That concludes our prepared remarks. And with that, we'll now take questions.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: At Mobile World Congress, it seems like everyone is racing -- and this is for Mike, there's a race to launch quad core. And first of all, congratulations on the top 15, top 20 you've had with Tegra 2. But the question I have on quad core is, first of all,
componenttext: At Mobile World Congress, it seems like everyone is racing -- and this is for Mike, there's a race to launch quad core. And first of all, congratulations on the top 15, top 20 you've had with Tegra 2. But the question I have on quad core is, first of all, is there enough application now to take advantage of this level of power that you are bringing in at the end of this year? And then secondly, do you need 28 nanometers to make this profitably? Can you talk about the economics of that?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Uche, so Quad core. It is the case that several of our competitors announced quad core products that will be sampled next year and potentially go into production the year after. At the Mobile World Congress, we demonstrated Kal-El, and there were quite a
componenttext: Uche, so Quad core. It is the case that several of our competitors announced quad core products that will be sampled next year and potentially go into production the year after. At the Mobile World Congress, we demonstrated Kal-El, and there were quite a few systems on-hand for demonstrating all aspects of  Kal-El. There was extreme high-definition video. It has the ability to support very high definition displays. The overall horsepower and computational capability of Kal-El is about 5x the performance of Tegra 2, and has some really exciting new technology for extremely low-powered operations even though we have four CPUs inside our Kal-El processor. These are all the breakthroughs that we have demonstrated at Mobile World Congress. Whereas some of the competitors seem panicked to announce something on their powerpoint slides, we tend to announce the product when we're actually sampling to customers. And in the case of Kal-El, we're now sampling to our strategic partners and our intention is to go to production this year. With respect to the importance of quad core, obviously, quad core is incredibly important otherwise it wouldn't be on all of the suppliers' road maps. We were the first in the world to announce and ship dual core. During that time, a lot of people asked us about that, and now it's quad core. If you think about the tablet or mobile device applications, you'll realize that very quickly the multitasking. You're multitasking whether you're streaming music, while you're reading a book or you're playing game and you're being connected to other players in a multiplayer environment. Or you're doing physics processing while you're playing the game, one of the most delightful parts of the game that people like these days, whether it's Angry Bird or others, it's just the realistic physics that it does. And the way that the bricks and the buildings fall apart are physically real, and you'll going to see more and more of that type of capability over time. And so whether it's multitasking, whether it's image processing for very high-quality camera effects, browsing, multitasking, those type of applications are all very, very intensive users of multi GPU cores. And the last thing is it's actually logical and completely intuitive if you think about it, but four CPU cores working less hard consumes less energy than one CPU core or two CPU cores working their butt off. And that's the reason why if you look at the PC industry, what people have said about the PC hitting the brick wall and hitting the power wall. Remember when CPUs were cranking at extreme high frequencies, those are just bad ideas. Brute forcing CPU design and overclocking it and causing it to run extremely fast is just not a very good idea. It makes a lot more sense to run it at the natural frequency of the semiconductor process and utilize all kinds of parallels and ideas. In the case of CPUs, we have four cores. In the case of GPU, we have 12 cores. Using parallelism is the most efficient and also the highest performance approach to computing that we know.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the economics, will it be done [ph] by 28 nanometers?
componenttext: In terms of the economics, will it be done [ph] by 28 nanometers?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, 28 nanometers is not available yet, so it's not an option this year. On the other hand, 40 nanometers is actually more economical than 28 nanometers this year and will likely expected to be so until about first half, maybe even the midpoint of next
componenttext: Well, 28 nanometers is not available yet, so it's not an option this year. On the other hand, 40 nanometers is actually more economical than 28 nanometers this year and will likely expected to be so until about first half, maybe even the midpoint of next year. So 40 nanometers is absolutely the right approach. It is the most mature, and we can go into very, very high production, very, very quickly because the yields are so great.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Emily calling in for Ambrish. For the Tegra business, can you comment on the mix of that between smartphones and tablets today and where you see that as we exit the year?
componenttext: This is Emily calling in for Ambrish. For the Tegra business, can you comment on the mix of that between smartphones and tablets today and where you see that as we exit the year?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard to tell because it depends on how many smartphones and tablets are partners cell. And so it's really, really hard to tell. I mean, one of the things that we all have to recognize is the market for tablets is much, much larger than we all e
componenttext: Well, it's hard to tell because it depends on how many smartphones and tablets are partners cell. And so it's really, really hard to tell. I mean, one of the things that we all have to recognize is the market for tablets is much, much larger than we all expected. And every single time an analyst comes out with another projection for the size of the tablet market it gets bigger, and I think there's a couple of reasons for that. They're just wonderfully delightful to use. They're easy to carry around and you see more and more people now carrying around tablets surely instead of -- I've never seen anybody carry a netbook around. But you see more and more people carry tablets around than notebooks. And also, even if you have a PC, you don't mind buying a tablet to supplement it. If you already got a PC, it's not likely you buy another PC. But you surely would buy a tablet to supplement it. So I think it's an easy purchase. It's easy to use and delightful to use. And so I think people are surprised by the size of the tablet market. My sense is that we're going to continue to be surprised by the size of the tablet market, certainly as more and more capabilities come out. One of the things that we're really excited about is that these tablets are now completely flash accelerated. And so you can go to any website, you could rent any application off the Web that you expect to. And so those kinds of new usage capabilities and this freedom to explore capability is something that we're quite excited about. And so it's hard for us to tell right now. The thing that I can tell you is that our design wins are all Tier 1s. I mean, these are the marquee names of the mobile industry and the computing industry and have a great deal of faith in their ability to create exciting products and taking them to market. And so we'll just have to wait and see and see how it turns out.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then within the GPU segment, can you comment on your expectation for ASPs on desktops and notebooks as the Sandy Bridge systems are rolled out?
componenttext: And then within the GPU segment, can you comment on your expectation for ASPs on desktops and notebooks as the Sandy Bridge systems are rolled out?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our ASPs, it depends on two factors. On the one hand, most of the notebook ASPs are going to be lower than the GTX 580 and 570 to 560, which was recently rolled out. On the other hand, the GTX 570 and 560 are still ramping. And so it's hard to say exactly
componenttext: Our ASPs, it depends on two factors. On the one hand, most of the notebook ASPs are going to be lower than the GTX 580 and 570 to 560, which was recently rolled out. On the other hand, the GTX 570 and 560 are still ramping. And so it's hard to say exactly how it's going to play out. We're just going to have to report on the progress as we go. We're excited about the gamers market. The gamers market has three catalysts this year. One, there's some really, really big titles of PC game coming out: Crysis 2. It's just really, really exciting. And so I think the enthusiasts come out when there is a great new breakthrough games like Crysis. The second thing is it's been a long time since the PC gamers had a basic platform of great opportunity. Sandy Bridge is the best CPU that's been built on for PC gamers in a long, long time. And so we have SLI motherboards with Intel. We have SLI motherboards with ASUSTeK, with Gigabyte, with many others, so that gamers can upgrade their PCs with affordable, very low-powered and very high-performance systems. And so when Sandy Bridge starts to ramp and the SLI motherboards start the ship here in the near future, we're going to have to see how many people come up with the upgrade. And then lastly, there's 3D Vision. When you can enjoy looking in 3D, it's just much more exciting. And 3D Vision basically doubles the resolution one for each eye, doubles the resolution that is needed to enjoy a game. And so that tends to drive higher end ASPs. And so we're just going to have to wait and see before we can tell for sure.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: On Tegra, obviously, the team has a rapid ramp ahead of them and I think the concern with anything associated with the mobile and retail space is how do you monitor sell-through to the end markets and to consumers and then to kind of triangulate that with
componenttext: On Tegra, obviously, the team has a rapid ramp ahead of them and I think the concern with anything associated with the mobile and retail space is how do you monitor sell-through to the end markets and to consumers and then to kind of triangulate that with the orders that you're getting from your handset and your tablet customers. So maybe you can take us through how the team plans to keep a close eye on sell into to your customers versus sell-through to the end markets?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the way we look at that is in our larger businesses like Quadro and GeForce, we put a lot of energy into monitoring sell-outs and sell-throughs. And the reason for that is because we're such a large position in the marketplace. Tegra is a brand new
componenttext: Well, the way we look at that is in our larger businesses like Quadro and GeForce, we put a lot of energy into monitoring sell-outs and sell-throughs. And the reason for that is because we're such a large position in the marketplace. Tegra is a brand new product for us, and we have almost zero exposure in the mobile industry and this is really our first major push into it. And the devices that we're in are not fringe or exotic devices. They're not transformer-type devices or new 3D displays where people aren't sure yet whether those adoptions are quite higher or not. These are straight-down-the-middle, high-end and where-the-demand-is-the-greatest superphone devices right now. And as you see from the device, they're beautiful and they're the primary platforms for the marquee customers that we're working with. It is core to their business. These aren't fringe products. And so I think that from that perspective, I have relative amount of confidence that our partners are going to do a great job marketing them. And the enthusiasm in the marketplace is already really, really high and the reviews have been great. So my sense is that we're going to do quite well. As we get to be a much larger player in the mobile space, we're going to have to develop those kind of systems that we use for the PC industry where we monitor sell-throughs and sell-outs. And so we're going to have to continue to do a better job with that. But at the moment, I think that we're going into, I guess, what people will consider blue ocean [ph].
